paras.en: August is the Sun. Me and Mom and Dad are planets orbiting the Sun. The rest of our family and friends are asteroids and comets floating around the planets orbiting the Sun. The only celestial body that doesn't orbit August the Sun is Daisy the dog, and that's only because to her little doggy eyes, August's face doesn't look very different from any other human's face. To Daisy, all our faces look alike, as flat and pale as the moon.
paras.cn: 奥古斯特是太阳。我、妈妈和爸爸是围绕太阳运行的行星。我们家其余的亲戚和朋友是漂浮在行星周围、围绕太阳运行的小行星和彗星。唯一不围绕太阳奥古斯特运行的天体是小狗黛西，而那仅仅是因为在她小小的狗眼睛里，奥古斯特的脸和任何其他人类的脸看起来没什么不同。对黛西来说，我们所有的脸都长得一样，像月亮一样平坦而苍白。

vocab.ex: The Earth orbits the Sun once every year.
Scientists are tracking a large asteroid that will pass near Earth.
We stayed up late to watch the comet streak across the night sky.
A star is a type of celestial body that produces its own light.
The two sisters look so much alike that it's hard to tell them apart.

gram.name: 扩展隐喻（太阳系）
gram.pattern: A central metaphor is established and then developed throughout a passage.
gram.function: 通过将家庭关系比作一个太阳系（August是太阳，家人是行星等），作者建立了一个贯穿全文的核心隐喻。这不仅仅是一个简单的比较，而是一个完整的系统，生动地展示了整个家庭的生活是如何围绕August的特殊需求运转的，为章节设定了核心主题。

example.en: She described her argument with him as a chess game, where every move was carefully calculated.
example.cn: 她把与他的争论描述为一盘棋，每一步都经过精心计算。

gram.constraints: 是一种复杂的文学手法，用于构建主题和意象。

paras.en: I'm used to the way this universe works. I've never minded it because it's all I've ever known. I've always understood that August is special and has special needs. If I was playing too loudly and he was trying to take a nap, I knew I would have to play something else because he needed his rest after some procedure or other had left him weak and in pain. If I wanted Mom and Dad to watch me play soccer, I knew that nine out of ten times they'd miss it because they were busy shuttling August to speech therapy or physical therapy or a new specialist or a surgery.
paras.cn: 我已经习惯了这个宇宙的运作方式。我从未介意过，因为这是我所知道的一切。我一直都明白奥古斯特是特别的，有特殊的需求。如果我玩得太大声而他正想小睡，我知道我将不得不玩点别的，因为在某个手术或其他什么事之后，他需要休息，那时他会很虚弱和疼痛。如果我想让爸爸妈妈看我踢足球，我知道十有八九他们会错过，因为他们忙于接送奥古斯特去做语言治疗、物理治疗、看新的专科医生或做手术。

vocab.ex: Do you mind if I open the window?
The school has excellent resources for children with special needs.
He is recovering well after the minor surgical procedure.
Nine out of ten times, he's late for our meetings.
A bus shuttles guests between the airport and the hotel.
The child attends speech therapy twice a week to improve his pronunciation.

gram.name: 过去真实条件句（用于描述习惯）
gram.pattern: If + past tense, ... knew + would have to...
gram.function: 用于描述过去反复发生的、真实的因果关系或行为模式，而非一次性的虚拟假设。'If I was playing too loudly..., I knew I would have to...' 描述了过去一种常规的、可预见的家庭动态。

example.en: Back then, if the weather was nice, we would always go to the park.
example.cn: 那时候，如果天气好，我们总会去公园。

gram.constraints: 描述的是一种过去的习惯性现实。

paras.en: Mom and Dad would always say I was the most understanding little girl in the world. I don't know about that, just that I understood there was no point in complaining. I've seen August after his surgeries: his little face bandaged up and swollen, his tiny body full of IVs and tubes to keep him alive. After you've seen someone else going through that, it feels kind of crazy to complain over not getting the toy you had asked for, or your mom missing a school play. I knew this even when I was six years old. No one ever told it to me. I just knew it.
paras.cn: 爸爸妈妈总会说我是世界上最善解人意的小女孩。我不知道是不是这样，只知道我明白抱怨是毫无意义的。我见过奥古斯特手术后的样子：他小小的脸被绷带包着，肿胀着，他小小的身体插满了维持他生命的静脉输液管和各种管子。在你见过别人经历那些之后，为没得到你想要的玩具，或你妈妈错过了学校戏剧而抱怨，感觉有点疯狂。我甚至六岁的时候就明白这一点了。从来没有人告诉过我。我就是知道。

vocab.ex: She was very understanding when I explained my situation.
There's no point in arguing with him; he'll never change his mind.
His arm was all bandaged up after the accident.
Her ankle was swollen after she twisted it.

vocab.mean: 静脉输液管和各种插管
vocab.ex: The patient was connected to several IVs and tubes.

gram.name: 比较性论证
gram.pattern: After [extreme experience], it feels [adjective] to [lesser action].
gram.function: 通过将自己的小烦恼与弟弟所经受的巨大痛苦进行对比，来论证“抱怨”行为的“疯狂”或不合理性。这是一种强大的修辞手法，用于建立视角并解释自己情感反应的逻辑。

example.en: After you've climbed a real mountain, it feels silly to complain about walking up a small hill.
example.cn: 在你爬过一座真正的山之后，为爬一个小山丘而抱怨就感觉很傻。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来建立观点和情感合理性的有效方式。

paras.en: So I've gotten used to not complaining, and I've gotten used to not bothering Mom and Dad with little stuff. I've gotten used to figuring things out on my own: how to put toys together, how to organize my life so I don't miss friends' birthday parties, how to stay on top of my schoolwork so I never fall behind in class. I've never asked for help with my homework. Never needed reminding to finish a project or study for a test. If I was having trouble with a subject in school, I'd go home and study it until I figured it out on my own. I taught myself how to convert fractions into decimal points by going online. I've done every school project pretty much by myself. When Mom or Dad ask me how things are going in school, I've always said "good"—even when it hasn't always been so good. My worst day, worst fall, worst headache, worst bruise, worst cramp, worst mean thing anyone could say has always been nothing compared to what August has gone through.
paras.cn: 所以我习惯了不抱怨，也习惯了不拿小事去烦爸爸妈妈。我习惯了自己解决问题：如何把玩具拼装起来，如何安排我的生活以免错过朋友的生日派对，如何紧跟我的学业以免在课堂上落后。我从没在家庭作业上寻求过帮助。从不需要被提醒去完成一个项目或为考试学习。如果我在学校里某门科目上遇到困难，我就会回家自己研究，直到我自己弄明白为止。我通过上网自学了如何将分数转换为小数。我几乎所有的学校项目都是自己完成的。当爸爸妈妈问我在学校情况如何时，我总是说“很好”——即使情况并非总是那么好。我最糟糕的一天、最惨的一次摔倒、最厉害的头痛、最严重的瘀伤、最剧烈的抽筋、任何人能说的最刻薄的话，与奥古斯特所经历的相比，都一直算不了什么。

vocab.ex: It took a while for him to get used to his new job.
I'm sorry to bother you, but could you help me with this?

vocab.word: figure things out on one's own
vocab.ex: When he moved to a new city, he had to figure things out on his own.
It's hard to stay on top of all the new technology.
If you miss too many classes, you might fall behind.
You need to convert the file to a different format.
He had a large bruise on his arm after falling off his bike.
She got a sudden cramp in her leg while swimming.
My little problem is nothing compared to the challenges she faces every day.

gram.name: 首语重复法 (用于强调自立)
gram.pattern: Repetition of phrases like 'I've gotten used to...' and 'I've never...'
gram.function: 通过重复 'I've gotten used to...' 和 'I've never...'，作者列举并强调了叙述者为了不给家人添麻烦而养成的一系列独立自主的行为。这种排比结构有力地展示了她的成熟和牺牲。

example.en: I've climbed mountains. I've sailed the seas. I've seen wonders. But I've never felt so alive as I do right now.
example.cn: 我曾攀登高山。我曾航行大海。我曾见证奇迹。但我从未像现在这样感觉如此充满活力。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过列举来建立人物性格的有效技巧。

paras.en: This isn't me being noble, by the way: it's just the way I know it is. And this is the way it's always been for me, for the little universe of us. But this year there seems to be a shift in the cosmos. The galaxy is changing. Planets are falling out of alignment.
paras.cn: 顺便说一下，我这不是在高尚：这只是我知道的事实而已。对我来说，对我们这个小小的宇宙来说，一直都是这样。但今年，宇宙似乎发生了变化。银河系正在改变。行星正在偏离轨道。

vocab.ex: It was a noble act to donate his entire fortune to charity.
I don't like the rules, but that's the way it is.
There has been a significant shift in public opinion on the matter.
Carl Sagan explored the wonders of the cosmos in his famous TV series.
After hitting the pothole, the wheels of my car were out of alignment.

gram.name: 重申隐喻以作铺垫
gram.pattern: Re-stating the initial metaphor + introducing a disruptive element.
gram.function: 通过回归并扩展开篇建立的“太阳系”隐喻，作者巧妙地预示了即将到来的变化和冲突。'Planets are falling out of alignment' 这一意象，暗示了家庭中既定的秩序和平衡正在被打破，为后续情节埋下伏笔。

example.en: My life had been a calm sea for years. But now, the storm clouds were gathering on the horizon.
example.cn: 多年来，我的生活一直是一片平静的海洋。但现在，暴风云正在地平线上聚集。

gram.constraints: 是一种将章节主题串联起来并制造悬念的文学技巧。

paras.en: I honestly don't remember my life before August came into it. I look at pictures of me as a baby, and I see Mom and Dad smiling so happily, holding me. I can't believe how much younger they looked back then: Dad was this hipster dude and Mom was this cute Brazilian fashionista. There's one shot of me at my third birthday: Dad's right behind me while Mom's holding the cake with three lit candles, and in back of us are Tata and Poppa, Grans, Uncle Ben, Aunt Kate, and Uncle Po. Everyone's looking at me and I'm looking at the cake. You can see in that picture how I really was the first child, first grandchild, first niece. I don't remember what it felt like, of course, but I can see it plain as can be in the pictures.
paras.cn: 老实说，我不记得奥古斯特出现之前我的生活是什么样的。我看着我还是婴儿时的照片，看到爸爸妈妈那么开心地笑着，抱着我。我简直不敢相信他们那时看起来有多年轻：爸爸是个时髦的潮人，妈妈是个可爱的巴西时尚达人。有一张我三岁生日的照片：爸爸就在我身后，妈妈举着插有三根点燃蜡烛的蛋糕，我们后面是塔塔和波帕、奶奶、本叔叔、凯特阿姨和波叔叔。每个人都看着我，而我正看着蛋糕。在那张照片里你可以看出我当时真的是第一个孩子、第一个孙辈、第一个侄女。当然，我不记得那是什么感觉，但在照片里我看得一清二楚。

vocab.ex: With his vintage glasses and beard, he looked like a typical hipster dude.
She's a true fashionista, always wearing the latest trends.
The photographer took a beautiful shot of the sunset.
The room was illuminated by the soft glow of a few lit candles.
The answer to the riddle was plain as can be once you thought about it.

gram.name: 同位语（用于描述）
gram.pattern: Noun + Noun Phrase (as description)
gram.function: 用于对前面的名词进行补充说明或重新定义。'Dad was this hipster dude' 和 'Mom was this cute Brazilian fashionista' 用名词短语来生动地描述父母当时的样子，功能上起到了同位语的作用。

example.en: My first car, a rusty old sedan, barely worked.
example.cn: 我的第一辆车，一辆生锈的旧轿车，几乎没法开。

gram.constraints: 是一种生动的描述性手法。

paras.en: I don't remember the day they brought August home from the hospital. I don't remember what I said or did or felt when I saw him for the first time, though everyone has a story about it. Apparently, I just looked at him for a long time without saying anything at all, and then finally I said: "It doesn't look like Lilly!" That was the name of a doll Grans had given me when Mom was pregnant so I could "practice" being a big sister. It was one of those dolls that are incredibly lifelike, and I had carried it everywhere for months, changing its diaper, feeding it. I'm told I even made a baby sling for it. The story goes that after my initial reaction to August, it only took a few minutes (according to Grans) or a few days (according to Mom) before I was all over him: kissing him, cuddling him, baby talking to him. After that I never so much as touched or mentioned Lilly ever again.
paras.cn: 我不记得他们把奥古斯特从医院带回家的那天。我不记得我第一次见到他时说了什么、做了什么或感觉到了什么，尽管每个人都有一套关于此事的说法。显然，我只是看了他很长时间，一句话也没说，然后最后我说：“他看起来不像莉莉！” 那是妈妈怀孕时奶奶送给我的一个娃娃的名字，这样我就可以“练习”当一个大姐姐。那是那种非常逼真的娃娃之一，我好几个月都把它带在身边，给它换尿布，喂它吃东西。据说我甚至还为它做了一个婴儿背带。故事是这样说的，在我对奥古斯特最初的反应之后，只过了几分钟（根据奶奶的说法）或几天（根据妈妈的说法），我就完全黏上他了：亲吻他，拥抱他，对他呀呀学语。那之后，我再也没有碰过或提过莉莉一次。

vocab.ex: Apparently, the meeting has been cancelled.
The wax figure was so lifelike it was almost creepy.
It's important to change a baby's diaper regularly.
She carried her newborn in a comfortable baby sling.
The story goes that the old house is haunted by a friendly ghost.
My initial reaction to the news was complete shock.

vocab.mean: 非常亲近某人；黏着某人
vocab.ex: The puppy was all over its new owner, licking his face.
The children love to cuddle with their parents on the sofa.
He left the party without so much as a goodbye.

gram.name: 被动语态（用于转述信息）
gram.pattern: Subject + be + past participle
gram.function: 用于陈述一个事实或转述信息，而不需要指明信息的来源或动作的执行者。'I'm told I even made a baby sling for it' 意思是“有人告诉我…”，是一种转述传闻的简洁方式。

example.en: It is said that the castle is over 500 years old.
example.cn: 据说这座城堡有超过500年的历史了。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的、较为客观的陈述方式。

paras.en: I never used to see August the way other people saw him. I knew he didn't look exactly normal, but I really didn't understand why strangers seemed so shocked when they saw him. Horrified. Sickened. Scared. There are so many words I can use to describe the looks on people's faces. And for a long time I didn't get it. I'd just get mad. Mad when they stared. Mad when they looked away. "What the heck are you looking at?" I'd say to people—even grown-ups.
paras.cn: 我过去从来不像别人那样看待奥古斯特。我知道他长得不完全正常，但我真的不明白为什么陌生人看到他时会显得那么震惊。惊恐。恶心。害怕。我可以用很多词来形容人们脸上的表情。很长一段时间里我都不理解。我只会生气。他们盯着看时我会生气。他们移开目光时我也会生气。“你看什么鬼东西？” 我会对人们说——即使是大人。

vocab.ex: She was horrified to see the car accident.
I felt sickened by the cruelty I witnessed.
The little boy was scared of the dark.
He explained the joke, but I still didn't get it.

vocab.mean: （非正式）到底是什么（用于加强疑问或愤怒语气）
vocab.ex: What the heck are you doing in my room?

gram.name: 使用片段进行列举以加强语气
gram.pattern: Adjective. Adjective. Adjective.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列语法上不完整的句子片段（全都是形容词），作者创造了一种快速、有力的节奏，生动地列举了人们看到主角弟弟时的各种极端反应，让读者立刻感受到那种冲击力。

example.en: The final scene. Explosions. Chaos. Unforgettable.
example.cn: 最后一幕。爆炸。混乱。令人难忘。

gram.constraints: 是一种文学和修辞手法，用于增强语气和节奏。

paras.en: Then, when I was about eleven, I went to stay with Grans in Montauk for four weeks while August was having his big jaw surgery. This was the longest I'd ever been away from home, and I have to say it was so amazing to suddenly be free of all that stuff that made me so mad. No one stared at Grans and me when we went to town to buy groceries. No one pointed at us. No one even noticed us.
paras.cn: 然后，在我大约十一岁的时候，我去蒙托克的奶奶家住了四个星期，当时奥古斯特正在做他的大型下颌手术。这是我离家最久的一次，我得说，突然摆脱了所有那些让我生气的事情，感觉真是太棒了。我们去镇上买食品杂货时，没人盯着奶奶和我看。没人指着我们。甚至没人注意到我们。

vocab.ex: He couldn't eat solid food for weeks after his jaw surgery.
The view from the mountaintop was absolutely amazing.
After finishing his final exam, he felt free of all stress.
I need to stop at the store to buy some groceries for dinner.

gram.name: 首语重复法 (No one...)
gram.pattern: Repetition of a phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
gram.function: 通过在连续的句子开头重复 'No one...'，作者建立了一种强烈的节奏感，并有力地强调了叙述者在奶奶家所体验到的“正常”和“不被注意”的解放感，与她平时在家里的生活形成鲜明对比。

example.en: No one called. No one wrote. No one seemed to care.
example.cn: 没人打电话。没人写信。似乎没人在乎。

gram.constraints: 是一种强有力的修辞手法，用于强调和增强情感。

paras.en: Grans was one of those grandmothers who do everything with their grandkids. She'd run into the ocean if I asked her to, even if she had nice clothes on. She would let me play with her makeup and didn't mind if I used it on her face to practice my face-painting skills. She'd take me for ice cream even if we hadn't eaten dinner yet. She'd draw chalk horses on the sidewalk in front of her house. One night, while we were walking back from town, I told her that I wished I could live with her forever. I was so happy there. I think it might have been the best time in my life.
paras.cn: 奶奶是那种会和孙辈一起做任何事的祖母。如果我让她跑进海里，她就会跑进去，即使她穿着漂亮的衣服。她会让我玩她的化妆品，而且不介意我用在她的脸上来练习我的脸部彩绘技巧。她会带我去吃冰淇淋，即使我们还没吃晚饭。她会在她家门前的人行道上画粉笔马。一天晚上，当我们从镇上走回来时，我告诉她我希望我能永远和她住在一起。我在那里太开心了。我想那可能是我一生中最美好的时光。

vocab.ex: She loves spending weekends with her grandkids.
She doesn't wear a lot of makeup, just some lipstick.
Face-painting is a popular activity at children's parties.
The children were drawing pictures on the sidewalk with colored chalk.

gram.name: 使用 'would' 表示过去习惯和意愿
gram.pattern: Subject + 'd (would) + infinitive
gram.function: 用于描述过去反复发生的习惯性动作或某人过去愿意做某事。'She'd run...', 'She would let me play...', 'She'd take me...', 'She'd draw...' 这一系列平行结构描绘了奶奶过去常做的、充满爱意的行为。

example.en: Every summer, my grandmother would bake us apple pies.
example.cn: 每年夏天，我奶奶都会给我们烤苹果派。

gram.constraints: 'would'不能用于描述过去的状态，只能用于描述动作。

paras.en: Coming home after four weeks felt very strange at first. I remember very vividly stepping through the door and seeing August running over to welcome me home, and for this tiny fraction of a moment I saw him not the way I've always seen him, but the way other people see him. It was only a flash, an instant while he was hugging me, so happy that I was home, but it surprised me because I'd never seen him like that before. And I'd never felt what I was feeling before, either: a feeling I hated myself for having the moment I had it. But as he was kissing me with all his heart, all I could see was the drool coming down his chin. And suddenly there I was, like all those people who would stare or look away. Horrified. Sickened. Scared.
paras.cn: 离家四周后回家，起初感觉非常奇怪。我非常清晰地记得，我一踏进门，就看到奥古斯特跑过来欢迎我回家，就在那极小的一瞬间，我看到的他不再是我一直以来看到的样子，而是别人看到的样子。那只是一闪而过，在他拥抱我、为我回家而高兴的一瞬间，但这让我很惊讶，因为我以前从未那样看过他。而且我也从未有过我当时的感受：一种我一产生就恨自己的感觉。但当他全心全意地亲吻我时，我所能看到的只有从他下巴流下的口水。突然间，我就在那里，就像所有那些会盯着看或移开目光的人一样。惊恐。恶心。害怕。

vocab.ex: I can vividly remember my first day of school.
For just a fraction of a moment, the room was completely silent.
I saw a flash of lightning in the distance.
The baby had some drool on his chin.
She loves her family with all her heart.

gram.name: not the way... but the way... (对比视角)
gram.pattern: not the way [perspective A], but the way [perspective B]
gram.function: 一个强有力的对比结构，用于区分两种不同的看待事物的方式或视角。'...not the way I've always seen him, but the way other people see him' 精确地描述了叙述者在那一瞬间发生的深刻的视角转变。

example.en: Try to see the problem not the way you always have, but the way a stranger would see it.
example.cn: 试着不要用你一贯的方式看待这个问题，而要用一个陌生人的视角来看待它。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示认知或视角变化的有效结构。

paras.en: Thankfully, that only lasted for a second: the moment I heard August laugh his raspy little laugh, it was over. Everything was back the way it had been before. But it had opened a door for me. A little peephole. And on the other side of the peephole there were two Augusts: the one I saw blindly, and the one other people saw.
paras.cn: 谢天谢地，那只持续了一秒钟：当我听到奥古斯特发出他那沙哑的小小笑声的那一刻，一切都结束了。所有事情都回到了以前的样子。但它为我打开了一扇门。一个小小的窥视孔。而在窥视孔的另一边，有两个奥古斯特：一个是我盲目地看到的那个，另一个是别人看到的那个。

vocab.ex: Thankfully, no one was injured in the accident.
The movie lasted for three hours.
He had a raspy voice from shouting too much at the game.
She looked through the peephole in the door before opening it.
Don't just blindly follow the crowd; think for yourself.

gram.name: 双重感知的隐喻
gram.pattern: A metaphor representing a new awareness.
gram.function: 通过使用“一扇门”和“一个窥视孔”的隐喻，作者将叙述者获得的全新视角具象化。这个意象生动地表达了一种新的、无法逆转的认知能力的开启，即她现在能够同时看到两个版本的弟弟：她所爱的和世界所看到的。

example.en: Reading that book was like opening a window onto a whole new world of ideas.
example.cn: 读那本书就像打开了一扇通往全新思想世界的窗户。

gram.constraints: 是一种将抽象的认知变化转化为具体意象的文学技巧。

paras.en: I think the only person in the world I could have told any of this to was Grans, but I didn't. It was too hard to explain over the phone. I thought maybe when she came for Thanksgiving, I'd tell her what I felt. But just two months after I stayed with her in Montauk, my beautiful Grans died. It was so completely out of the blue. Apparently, she had checked herself into the hospital because she'd been feeling nauseous. Mom and I drove out to see her, but it's a threehour drive from where we live, and by the time we got to the hospital, Grans was gone. A heart attack, they told us. Just like that.
paras.cn: 我想世界上唯一能让我倾诉这一切的人就是奶奶，但我没有。在电话里太难解释了。我想也许等她感恩节来的时候，我会告诉她我的感受。但在我住在蒙托克她家仅仅两个月后，我美丽的奶奶就去世了。这完全是出乎意料。显然，她自己去了医院，因为她一直感觉恶心。我和妈妈开车去看她，但从我们住的地方开过去要三个小时，等我们到医院时，奶奶已经走了。他们告诉我们，是心脏病发作。就那样。

vocab.ex: He called me out of the blue after years of no contact.
Feeling unwell, he checked himself into the emergency room.
The smell of the old food made her feel nauseous.
By the time we arrived, the movie had already started.
He was rushed to the hospital after suffering a massive heart attack.

vocab.mean: 就这样（表示事情发生得突然且简单）
vocab.ex: He was here a minute ago, and then, just like that, he was gone.

gram.name: By the time... (与过去完成时连用)
gram.pattern: by the time + clause (simple past), + clause (past perfect)
gram.function: 用于表示在过去某个动作（'we got to the hospital'）发生时，另一个动作（'Grans was gone'，此处 'was gone' 等同于 'had gone' 的状态）已经完成。它清晰地表明了两个过去动作的先后顺序。

example.en: By the time I finished my work, everyone else had already left.
example.cn: 等我完成工作时，其他所有人都已经离开了。

gram.constraints: 主句通常使用过去完成时。

paras.en: It's so strange how one day you can be on this earth, and the next day not. Where did she go? Will I really ever see her again, or is that a fairy tale? You see movies and TV shows where people receive horrible news in hospitals, but for us, with all our many trips to the hospital with August, there had always been good outcomes. What I remember the most from the day Grans died is Mom literally crumpling to the floor in slow, heaving sobs, holding her stomach like someone had just punched her. I've never, ever seen Mom like that. Never heard sounds like that come out of her. Even through all of August's surgeries, Mom always put on a brave face.
paras.cn: 真是奇怪，一天你还在这世上，第二天就不是了。她去哪儿了？我真的还能再见到她吗，还是那只是个童话？你看电影和电视剧，里面人们在医院里接到可怕的消息，但对我们来说，带着奥古斯特那么多次去医院，结果总归是好的。我记得奶奶去世那天最清楚的，是妈妈真的慢慢地瘫倒在地板上，剧烈地抽泣着，捂着肚子，就像有人刚打了她一拳。我从来、从来没有见过妈妈那样。也从未听过她发出那样的声音。即使在奥古斯特所有的手术中，妈妈总是装出一副勇敢的样子。

vocab.ex: He was the kindest person on this earth.
She doesn't believe in happy endings; she thinks they only happen in fairy tales.
It's too early to know the outcome of the election.
He crumpled the piece of paper into a ball and threw it away.
She broke down in heaving sobs when she heard the news.
Although he was nervous, he put on a brave face for his children.

gram.name: 强调句型 (What... is...)
gram.pattern: What + Subject + Verb + is + [emphasized part]
gram.function: 用于强调句子中的某个特定部分，通常是动作的对象或内容。'What I remember the most... is Mom literally crumpling to the floor...' 强调了她记忆中最深刻、最突出的画面。

example.en: What I need most right now is a glass of water.
example.cn: 我现在最需要的是一杯水。

gram.constraints: 由 'what' 引导的主语从句充当句子的主语。

paras.en: On my last day in Montauk, Grans and I had watched the sun set on the beach. We had taken a blanket to sit on, but it had gotten chilly, so we wrapped it around us and cuddled and talked until there wasn't even a sliver of sun left over the ocean. And then Grans told me she had a secret to tell me: she loved me more than anyone else in the world.
paras.cn: 在蒙托克的最后一天，奶奶和我曾在海滩上看过日落。我们带了一条毯子坐着，但天变冷了，所以我们把它裹在身上，依偎着聊天，直到大海上连一丝阳光都不剩。然后奶奶告诉我她有个秘密要告诉我：她爱我胜过世界上任何其他人。

vocab.ex: It's a bit chilly this morning; you should wear a jacket.
She wrapped a scarf around her neck to stay warm.
The children love to cuddle with their parents on the sofa.
She ate a small sliver of cake.

gram.name: not even (用于强调)
gram.pattern: not even + Noun Phrase
gram.function: 用于强调“连…都（不/没）”，突出某事的彻底性或程度之小。'...there wasn't even a sliver of sun left' 强调了太阳已经完全落山，一点点余晖都没有了，营造了一种终结和宁静的氛围。

example.en: He was so tired he couldn't even keep his eyes open.
example.cn: 他累得连眼睛都睁不开了。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的强调手法。

paras.en: "Even August?" I had asked. She smiled and stroked my hair, like she was thinking about what to say. "I love Auggie very, very much," she said softly. I can still remember her Portuguese accent, the way she rolled her r 's. "But he has many angels looking out for him already, Via. And I want you to know that you have me looking out for you. Okay, menina querida ? I want you to know that you are number one for me. You are my . . ." She looked out at the ocean and spread her hands out, like she was trying to smooth out the waves, "You are my everything. You understand me, Via? Tu es meu tudo."
paras.cn: “甚至超过奥吉吗？” 我曾问。她微笑着，抚摸着我的头发，好像在思考该说什么。“我非常、非常爱奥吉，” 她轻柔地说。我至今仍能记得她的葡萄牙口音，她发r的卷舌音。“但他已经有很多天使在守护他了，维娅。而我希望你知道，有我在守护你。好吗，亲爱的女孩？我希望你知道，你对我来说是第一位的。你是我的......” 她望向大海，张开双手，好像在试图抚平海浪，“你是我的一切。你明白吗，维娅？你是我的一切。”

vocab.ex: She gently stroked the cat's soft fur.
He speaks English with a strong French accent.
As the oldest brother, he always tried to look out for his younger siblings.
Her grandmother always called her 'menina querida'.
She used an iron to smooth out the wrinkles in her shirt.
He whispered to her, 'Tu es meu tudo,' expressing his deep love.

gram.name: 语码转换/使用外语
gram.pattern: Switching between languages within a conversation.
gram.function: 在以英语为主的对话中插入外语短语（'menina querida', 'Tu es meu tudo'），可以用来强调人物的文化背景（葡萄牙裔），并创造一种非常亲密、特殊的交流氛围。这些短语承载了比英语翻译更深的情感。

example.en: She ended every phone call with her grandmother by saying, 'Te quiero, abuela.'
example.cn: 她每次和祖母通完电话都会说：‘我爱你，奶奶。’

gram.constraints: 是一种表现人物身份和亲密关系的有效技巧。

paras.en: I understood her. And I knew why she said it was a secret. Grandmothers aren't supposed to have favorites. Everyone knows that. But after she died, I held on to that secret and let it cover me like a blanket.
paras.cn: 我明白她。我也知道她为什么说那是个秘密。祖母们是不应该有偏爱的。每个人都知道。但在她去世后，我紧紧抓住那个秘密，让它像一条毯子一样覆盖着我。

vocab.ex: Can you keep a secret?
You were supposed to finish your homework before watching TV.
It's not fair for a parent to have a favorite child.
She decided to hold on to her old car for another year.
On a cold night, it's nice to curl up with a warm blanket.

gram.name: 结论性明喻
gram.pattern: ... like a [noun].
gram.function: 在段落或章节的结尾使用一个强有力的明喻，可以创造一个令人难忘的、充满情感的总结。'let it cover me like a blanket' 将抽象的“秘密”比作具体的“毯子”，生动地传达了奶奶的话语所带来的持续的安慰、温暖和保护感。

example.en: His kind words were like a light in the darkness.
example.cn: 他友善的话语就像黑暗中的一道光。

gram.constraints: 是一种极具文学性的收尾技巧。

paras.en: His eyes are about an inch below where they should be on his face, almost to halfway down his cheeks. They slant downward at an extreme angle, almost like diagonal slits that someone cut into his face, and the left one is noticeably lower than the right one. They bulge outward because his eye cavities are too shallow to accommodate them. The top eyelids are always halfway closed, like he's on the verge of sleeping. The lower eyelids sag so much they almost look like a piece of invisible string is pulling them downward: you can see the red part on the inside, like they're almost inside out.
paras.cn: 他的眼睛在他脸上应在位置的下方约一英寸处，几乎到了他脸颊的一半。它们以一个极端的角度向下倾斜，几乎像有人在他脸上割开的斜缝，而且左眼明显低于右眼。它们向外凸出，因为他的眼眶太浅，无法容纳它们。上眼睑总是半闭着，就像他快要睡着了似的。下眼睑下垂得厉害，几乎像有一根无形的线在把它们往下拉：你可以看到里面的红色部分，好像它们几乎是里外翻过来了。

vocab.ex: The roof of the old shed began to slant downward after the heavy snow.
He peeked through a narrow slit in the curtains.
The old stone wall had started to bulge outward in the middle.
The dentist found a small cavity in one of my teeth.
The small hotel can only accommodate a limited number of guests.
She was on the verge of tears after hearing the sad news.
The old mattress began to sag in the middle.

gram.name: 描述性明喻
gram.pattern: ... like + Noun Phrase/Clause
gram.function: 通过使用一系列生动的明喻（'almost like diagonal slits', 'like he's on the verge of sleeping', 'almost look like a piece of invisible string'）来将复杂的、不寻常的面部特征与读者熟悉的事物进行类比，使得描述更加具体、形象和具有冲击力。

example.en: His voice was deep, like thunder rolling in the distance.
example.cn: 他的声音很低沉，就像远处滚动的雷声。

gram.constraints: 是文学描述中创造生动意象的核心技巧。

paras.en: He doesn't have eyebrows or eyelashes. His nose is disproportionately big for his face, and kind of fleshy. His head is pinched in on the sides where the ears should be, like someone used giant pliers and crushed the middle part of his face. He doesn't have cheekbones. There are deep creases running down both sides of his nose to his mouth, which gives him a waxy appearance. Sometimes people assume he's been burned in a fire: his features look like they've been melted, like the drippings on the side of a candle. Several surgeries to correct his palate have left a few scars around his mouth, the most noticeable one being a jagged gash running from the middle of his upper lip to his nose. His upper teeth are small and splay out. He has a severe overbite and an extremely undersized jawbone.
paras.cn: 他没有眉毛和睫毛。他的鼻子相对于他的脸来说大得不成比例，而且有点肉感。他的头在应该长耳朵的两侧向内凹陷，就像有人用巨大的钳子夹碎了他脸的中间部分。他没有颧骨。从他鼻子的两侧到嘴巴有深深的皱褶，这让他看起来有种蜡像的感觉。有时人们以为他被火烧过：他的五官看起来像是融化了，就像蜡烛侧面的蜡滴。几次矫正他腭裂的手术在他嘴周围留下了一些疤痕，最明显的一道是从上唇中间一直延伸到鼻子的锯齿状伤口。他的上牙很小，向外张开。他有严重的上颚突出和极度过小的颌骨。

vocab.ex: The small car had disproportionately large wheels.
Tomatoes are a type of fleshy fruit.
The corset was designed to pinch in the waist.
He used a pair of pliers to bend the wire.
She ironed the shirt to remove the creases.
The plant has thick, waxy leaves.
The roast chicken produced a lot of tasty drippings for gravy.
The broken glass had a sharp, jagged edge.
He had a long gash on his arm from the fall.
The dancer's feet would splay out in an unnatural position.
The orthodontist said he needed braces to correct his overbite.
He was wearing an undersized jacket that was too tight for him.

gram.name: 客观描述性语言
gram.pattern: A series of factual, non-emotional statements.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列冷静、客观、近乎临床的语言来描述奥古斯特的面部特征，作者创造了一种强烈的反差效果。这种不带感情色彩的描述，反而比情绪化的语言更能突显其外貌的“异常”，让读者自己去感受其中的冲击力。

example.en: The building was made of concrete. It had no windows. The door was made of steel.
example.cn: 那栋建筑是混凝土造的。它没有窗户。门是钢制的。

gram.constraints: 通过避免使用情感词汇来增强描述的力度。

paras.en: He has a very small chin. When he was very little, before a piece of his hip bone was surgically implanted into his lower jaw, he really had no chin at all. His tongue would just hang out of his mouth with nothing underneath to block it. Thankfully, it's better now. He can eat, at least: when he was younger, he had a feeding tube. And he can talk. And he's learned to keep his tongue inside his mouth, though that took him several years to master. He's also learned to control the drool that used to run down his neck. These are considered miracles. When he was a baby, the doctors didn't think he'd live.
paras.cn: 他的下巴很小。在他很小的时候，在一块髋骨被手术植入他的下颌之前，他真的完全没有下巴。他的舌头会直接挂在嘴外，下面没有任何东西可以挡住它。谢天谢地，现在好多了。他至少能吃东西了：他更小的时候，曾用过喂食管。他也能说话。而且他已经学会了把舌头收在嘴里，尽管他花了好几年才掌握。他也学会了控制以前会流到脖子上的口水。这些都被认为是奇迹。他还是个婴儿时，医生们以为他活不下来。

vocab.ex: He rested his chin in his hand, deep in thought.
The tumor was surgically removed.
The doctor will implant the device under the skin.
Be careful not to let your arms hang out of the moving car's window.
After the surgery, the patient had to be fed through a feeding tube.
It takes years of practice to master a musical instrument.
The baby had some drool on his chin.
It was a miracle that he survived the accident.

gram.name: 对比过去与现在的能力
gram.pattern: Past inability vs. Present ability
gram.function: 通过一系列过去（'had a feeding tube'）与现在（'He can eat'）的能力对比，作者强调了奥古斯特所取得的巨大进步。将这些基本的生活技能（吃、说）定义为“奇迹”，深刻地突显了他成长过程的艰辛。

example.en: He couldn't walk a year ago, but now he can run marathons.
example.cn: 一年前他还不能走路，但现在他能跑马拉松了。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示进步和变化的有效叙事方式。

paras.en: He can hear, too. Most kids born with these types of birth defects have problems with their middle ears that prevent them from hearing, but so far August can hear well enough through his tiny cauliflower-shaped ears. The doctors think that eventually he'll need to wear hearing aids, though. August hates the thought of this. He thinks the hearing aids will get noticed too much. I don't tell him that the hearing aids would be the least of his problems, of course, because I'm sure he knows this.
paras.cn: 他也能听见。大多数天生有这类出生缺陷的孩子，中耳都有问题，导致他们无法听见，但到目前为止，奥古斯特通过他小小的、菜花状的耳朵能听得足够清楚。不过，医生们认为他最终将需要戴助听器。奥古斯特讨厌这个想法。他认为助听器会太引人注目。我当然不会告诉他助听器会是他问题中最小的一个，因为我确定他知道这一点。

vocab.ex: The hospital specializes in treating children with rare birth defects.
The heavy rain prevented us from going to the beach.
So far, I have completed three chapters of the book.
The cloud had a strange, cauliflower-shaped appearance.
My grandfather wears a hearing aid in his left ear.

vocab.mean: 某人问题中最小的一个
vocab.ex: Forgetting my umbrella was the least of my problems when my car broke down in the rain.

gram.name: 未说出口的理解
gram.pattern: I don't tell him [obvious truth], because I'm sure he knows.
gram.function: 通过描述一个角色选择不去说出某个残酷但显而易见的真相，作者深刻地展现了角色之间的同理心和 unspoken understanding（默契）。这比直接的对话更能体现叙述者对弟弟的爱护和对他的成熟度的尊重。

example.en: I didn't tell her the dress looked bad on her, because I could see in her eyes she already knew.
example.cn: 我没告诉她那件裙子她穿着不好看，因为我能从她眼中看出她已经知道了。

gram.constraints: 是一种展示人物关系深度和复杂性的高级叙事技巧。

paras.en: Then again, I'm not really sure what August knows or doesn't know, what he understands and doesn't understand. Does August see how other people see him, or has he gotten so good at pretending not to see that it doesn't bother him? Or does it bother him? When he looks in the mirror, does he see the Auggie Mom and Dad see, or does he see the Auggie everyone else sees? Or is there another August he sees, someone in his dreams behind the misshapen head and face? Sometimes when I looked at Grans, I could see the pretty girl she used to be underneath the wrinkles. I could see the girl from Ipanema inside the old-lady walk. Does August see himself as he might have looked without that single gene that caused the catastrophe of his face?
paras.cn: 不过话说回来，我并不真的确定奥古斯特知道什么或不知道什么，他理解什么或不理解什么。奥古斯特能看到别人是怎么看他的吗，还是他已经变得太擅长假装没看见以至于那不会困扰他了？或者那真的会困扰他吗？当他照镜子时，他看到的是爸爸妈妈眼中的那个奥吉，还是他看到的是其他所有人眼中的那个奥吉？或者他看到了另一个奥吉，一个在他梦中、在畸形的头和脸背后的某个人？有时候当我看着奶奶时，我能从皱纹之下看到她曾经的美丽女孩模样。我能从老太太的步态中看到伊帕内玛的女孩。奥古斯特是否将自己看作是如果没有那个导致他面部灾难的单一基因，他本可能的样子呢？

vocab.ex: I want to go to the party. Then again, I'm really tired.
With practice, you can get good at playing the guitar.
Don't let his negative comments bother you.
The old tree had a gnarled, misshapen trunk.
He found a hidden key underneath the welcome mat.
Eye color is determined by a combination of genes from your parents.
The earthquake was a terrible catastrophe for the small town.

gram.name: 系列反问句
gram.pattern: A series of questions used to explore a complex idea.
gram.function: 通过提出一系列关于弟弟内心世界的、二元对立的反问句（'Does he see A or B?'），叙述者并非在寻求答案，而是在探索一个无法触及的复杂主题——他人的主观意识。这种手法深刻地展现了她对弟弟的同理心、困惑以及姐弟之间存在的隔阂。

example.en: Was it the right choice? Or did I make a huge mistake? Will I ever know for sure?
example.cn: 那是正确的选择吗？还是我犯了个大错？我能有确切知道的一天吗？

gram.constraints: 是一种展现内心挣扎和深度思考的文学技巧。

paras.en: I wish I could ask him this stuff. I wish he would tell me how he feels. He used to be easier to read before the surgeries. You knew that when his eyes squinted, he was happy. When his mouth went straight, he was being mischievous. When his cheeks trembled, he was about to cry. He looks better now, no doubt about that, but the signs we used to gauge his moods are all gone. There are new ones, of course. Mom and Dad can read every single one. But I'm having trouble keeping up. And there's a part of me that doesn't want to keep trying: why can't he just say what he's feeling like everyone else? He doesn't have a trache tube in his mouth anymore that keeps him from talking. His jaw's not wired shut. He's ten years old. He can use his words. But we circle around him like he's still the baby he used to be. We change plans, go to plan B, interrupt conversations, go back on promises depending on his moods, his whims, his needs. That was fine when he was little. But he needs to grow up now. We need to let him, help him, make him grow up. Here's what I think: we've all spent so much time trying to make August think he's normal that he actually thinks he is normal. And the problem is, he's not.
paras.cn: 我希望我能问他这些事。我希望他会告诉我他的感受。在手术之前，他过去更容易被读懂。你知道当他眼睛眯起来时，他是开心的。当他嘴巴抿成一条直线时，他是在淘气。当他脸颊颤抖时，他快要哭了。他现在看起来好多了，毫无疑问，但我们过去用来判断他情绪的那些迹象都消失了。当然，有新的迹象。爸爸妈妈能读懂每一个。但我正费力地跟上。而且我内心有一部分不想再继续尝试了：为什么他就不能像其他人一样说出自己的感受呢？他嘴里不再有阻碍他说话的气管插管了。他的下巴也没被钢丝固定住。他十岁了。他可以用语言表达。但我们像他还曾是那个婴儿一样围绕着他。我们根据他的情绪、他的奇想、他的需求来改变计划、启动B计划、打断对话、违背承诺。他小的时候那样没问题。但他现在需要长大了。我们需要让他、帮助他、促使他长大。我的想法是这样的：我们所有人都花了太多时间试图让奥古斯特认为他很正常，以至于他真的认为自己正常了。而问题是，他不是。

vocab.ex: She was hard to read; I never knew what she was thinking.
He had to squint to read the tiny print on the label.
The mischievous child hid his brother's favorite toy.
His hands started to tremble with fear.
It's difficult to gauge his reaction because he never shows his emotions.
She walked so fast I couldn't keep up with her.
After the accident, he needed a trache tube to help him breathe.
The children would circle around their grandmother to hear her stories.
He bought the expensive car on a whim, and later regretted it.

gram.name: 平行结构（使役动词）
gram.pattern: let him, help him, make him + infinitive
gram.function: 通过并列使用三个带有递进意味的使役动词（'let him' 允许, 'help him' 帮助, 'make him' 促使），作者创造了一种强烈的、富有节奏感的呼吁，强调了家庭需要采取更主动的角色来促进弟弟的成长。

example.en: We must guide them, teach them, and empower them to succeed.
example.cn: 我们必须引导他们、教导他们并赋予他们成功的力量。

gram.constraints: 是一种非常有力的修辞手法，用于表达强烈的意图或呼吁。

paras.en: What I always loved most about middle school was that it was separate and different from home. I could go there and be Olivia Pullman—not Via, which is my name at home. Via was what they called me in elementary school, too. Back then, everyone knew all about us, of course. Mom used to pick me up after school, and August was always in the stroller. There weren't a lot of people who were equipped to babysit for Auggie, so Mom and Dad brought him to all my class plays and concerts and recitals, all the school functions, the bake sales and the book fairs. My friends knew him. My friends' parents knew him. My teachers knew him. The janitor knew him. ("Hey, how ya doin', Auggie?" he'd always say, and give August a high five.) August was something of a fixture at PS 22.
paras.cn: 我一直最爱中学的一点是，它与家是分开且不同的。我可以去那里做奥利维亚·普尔曼——而不是维娅，那是我在家的名字。维娅也是他们在小学时叫我的名字。当然，那时候，每个人都知道我们家的一切。妈妈过去常常放学后接我，而奥古斯特总是在婴儿车里。没有很多人有能力照看奥吉，所以妈妈和爸爸带他参加我所有的班级戏剧、音乐会和独奏会，所有学校活动，烘焙义卖和书展。我的朋友们认识他。我朋友的父母认识他。我的老师们认识他。校工也认识他。（“嘿，你好吗，奥吉？”他总会说，然后和奥古斯特击个掌。）奥古斯特在22号公立学校算是个常客了。

vocab.ex: Keep your work life separate from your personal life.
Not everyone is emotionally equipped to handle such a stressful job.
She practiced for months for her piano recital.
Parents were invited to attend the annual school function.
The janitor makes sure the school is clean and safe.
The old man was a fixture at the local coffee shop, sitting in the same chair every day.

gram.name: 使用 'something of a' 进行修饰
gram.pattern: be + something of a + Noun
gram.function: 用于表示某人或某物在某种程度上具有某种特征，但又不是绝对或完全的。它是一种较为含蓄、委婉的说法。'August was something of a fixture' 意思是“奥古斯特算是个常客了”，比直接说 'August was a fixture' 语气更柔和。

example.en: He considers himself something of an expert on classic films.
example.cn: 他自认为算是个经典电影方面的专家。

gram.constraints: 是一种较为高级和地道的表达方式。

paras.en: But in middle school a lot of people didn't know about August. My old friends did, of course, but my new friends didn't. Or if they knew, it wasn't necessarily the first thing they knew about me. Maybe it was the second or third thing they'd hear about me. "Olivia? Yeah, she's nice. Did you hear she has a brother who's deformed?" I always hated that word, but I knew it was how people described Auggie. And I knew those kinds of conversations probably happened all the time out of earshot, every time I left the room at a party, or bumped into groups of friends at the pizza place. And that's okay. I'm always going to be the sister of a kid with a birth defect: that's not the issue. I just don't always want to be defined that way.
paras.cn: 但在中学，很多人不知道奥古斯特的事。当然，我的老朋友们知道，但我的新朋友们不知道。或者即使他们知道，那也未必是他们了解我的第一件事。也许是他们听说的关于我的第二或第三件事。“奥利维亚？嗯，她人不错。你听说她有个畸形的弟弟吗？” 我一直讨厌那个词，但我知道人们就是那样形容奥吉的。而且我知道那种对话可能总是在我听不到的地方发生，每当我在派对上离开房间，或是在披萨店碰到一群朋友时。那没关系。我永远会是一个有出生缺陷的孩子的姐姐：那不是问题所在。我只是不想总被那样定义。

vocab.ex: The most expensive option isn't necessarily the best one.
The accident left his hand permanently deformed.
They waited until the teacher was out of earshot before they started whispering.
I was surprised to bump into an old friend at the supermarket.
The hospital specializes in treating children with rare birth defects.
Money is not the issue; the real problem is a lack of trust.
Don't let one mistake define your entire career.

gram.name: 冒号（用于解释说明）
gram.pattern: Statement: Clarification.
gram.function: 用于引出对前面陈述的解释、举例或进一步说明。'...that's not the issue: I just don't always want to be defined that way' 中，冒号后面的部分澄清了前面“那不是问题所在”这句话的真正含义，即问题不在于“事实”本身，而在于“被定义”的方式。

example.en: I have a new rule for myself: no more procrastinating.
example.cn: 我给自己定了一个新规矩：不再拖延。

gram.constraints: 冒号前通常是一个完整的句子。

paras.en: The best thing about high school is that hardly anybody knows me at all. Except Miranda and Ella, of course. And they know not to go around talking about it. Miranda, Ella, and I have known each other since the first grade. What's so nice is we never have to explain things to one another. When I decided I wanted them to call me Olivia instead of Via, they got it without my having to explain. They've known August since he was a little baby. When we were little, our favorite thing to do was play dress up with Auggie; load him up with feather boas and big hats and Hannah Montana wigs. He used to love it, of course, and we thought he was adorably cute in his own way. Ella said he reminded her of E.T. She didn't say this to be mean, of course (though maybe it was a little bit mean). The truth is, there's a scene in the movie when Drew Barrymore dresses E.T. in a blond wig: and that was a ringer for Auggie in our Miley Cyrus heyday.
paras.cn: 高中最棒的一点是几乎没人认识我。当然，除了米兰达和埃拉。而且她们知道不要到处谈论这件事。米兰达、埃拉和我从一年级就认识了。最棒的是我们从不需要向彼此解释事情。当我决定我希望她们叫我奥利维亚而不是维娅时，她们不用我解释就明白了。她们从奥古斯特还是个小婴儿时就认识他了。我们小的时候，最喜欢做的事就是给奥吉玩装扮游戏；给他戴上羽毛围巾、大帽子和汉娜·蒙塔娜的假发。当然，他过去很喜欢，我们觉得他以他自己的方式可爱得不得了。埃拉说他让她想起了外星人E.T.。当然，她说这话不是为了刻薄（尽管也许有一点点刻薄）。事实是，电影里有一幕，德鲁·巴里摩尔给E.T.戴上了一顶金色假发：那简直就是我们在麦莉·赛勒斯全盛时期给奥吉打扮的样子。

vocab.ex: The party was a failure; hardly anybody came.
It's a complex joke, so don't worry if you don't get it at first.
The children love to dress up in their parents' clothes.
The actress wore a glamorous dress and a pink feather boa.
She wore a blond wig as part of her costume.
The little puppy was adorably clumsy.

vocab.mean: 与…长得一模一样的人/物
vocab.ex: With that beard, he's a dead ringer for his grandfather.
In its heyday, the company was the largest in the world.

gram.name: 现在完成时与since
gram.pattern: Present Perfect + since + point in time/clause
gram.function: 表示一个从过去某个时间点开始并持续到现在的动作或状态。'Miranda, Ella, and I have known each other since the first grade' 强调了她们友谊的持久性。

example.en: We have been friends since we were children.
example.cn: 我们从小就是朋友。

gram.constraints: since后面跟的是一个过去的时间点或一个描述过去动作的从句。

paras.en: Throughout middle school, Miranda, Ella, and I were pretty much our own little group. Somewhere between super popular and well-liked: not brainy, not jocks, not rich, not druggies, not mean, not goody-goody, not huge, not flat. I don't know if the three of us found each other because we were so alike in so many ways, or that because we found each other, we've become so alike in so many ways. We were so happy when we all got into Faulkner High School. It was such a long shot that all three of us would be accepted, especially when almost no one else from our middle school was.
paras.cn: 整个中学时期，米兰达、埃拉和我差不多是我们自己的小团体。介于超级受欢迎和人缘好之间：不是书呆子，不是运动员，不富有，不吸毒，不刻薄，不是乖乖牌，不高大，也不平胸。我不知道我们三个是因为在很多方面如此相像而找到了彼此，还是因为我们找到了彼此，才在很多方面变得如此相像。当我们都考入福克纳高中时，我们非常高兴。我们三个人都能被录取，可能性真是微乎其微，尤其是当我们中学几乎没有其他人被录取的时候。

vocab.ex: She was a great student throughout her time in college.
I've pretty much finished all my work for the day.
She was the brainy one in the group, always getting top grades.
The stereotype is that jocks are not very interested in academics.
No one liked him because he was such a goody-goody, always telling on others.
Winning the lottery is a real long shot, but it's fun to dream.
He was thrilled to receive his letter saying he was accepted to the university.

gram.name: 通过否定来定义
gram.pattern: A series of 'not X'.
gram.function: 通过列举一系列她们“不是”什么（'not brainy, not jocks...'），来反向定义她们这个小团体的位置和身份。这是一种巧妙的描述手法，通过排除法来界定一个“中间地带”的身份，比直接描述“是什么”更具层次感。

example.en: His style was unique: not flashy, not boring, not trendy, just his own.
example.cn: 他的风格很独特：不浮华，不无聊，不新潮，只是他自己的风格。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过排除来精确定位的修辞技巧。

paras.en: I remember how we screamed into our phones the day we got our acceptance letters. This is why I haven't understood what's been going on with us lately, now that we're actually in high school. It's nothing like how I thought it would be.
paras.cn: 我记得我们收到录取通知书那天，我们对着电话尖叫的样子。这就是为什么我不明白最近我们之间发生了什么，既然我们真的上了高中。这和我所想的完全不一样。

vocab.ex: She was so excited that she screamed into her pillow.
He jumped for joy when he received his acceptance letter from his dream university.
I haven't seen you in weeks! Tell me what's been going on.
Have you seen any good movies lately?
The movie was nothing like the book it was based on.

gram.name: This is why (连接因果)
gram.pattern: [Cause/Context]. This is why [Effect/Result].
gram.function: 用于将前面陈述的整个背景（她们深厚的友谊和共同的喜悦）作为原因，来解释后面提出的结果或困惑（'I haven't understood...'）。它建立了一个从过去到现在的清晰的因果链条，强调了当前状况的出乎意料。

example.en: He studied hard every single day. This is why he got the top score on the exam.
example.cn: 他每天都努力学习。这就是为什么他在考试中得了最高分。

gram.constraints: 'This' 指代的是前文所描述的整个情境。

paras.en: Out of the three of us, Miranda had almost always been the sweetest to August, hugging him and playing with him long after Ella and I had moved on to playing something else. Even as we got older, Miranda always made sure to try to include August in our conversations, ask him how he was doing, talk to him about Avatar or Star Wars or Bone or something she knew he liked. It was Miranda who had given Auggie the astronaut helmet he wore practically every day of the year when he was five or six. She would call him Major Tom and they would sing "Space Oddity" by David Bowie together. It was their little thing. They knew all the words and would blast it on the iPod and sing the song out loud.
paras.cn: 我们三个人当中，米兰达几乎总是对奥古斯特最甜美的那个，在埃拉和我已经转去玩别的东西很久之后，她还会拥抱他、和他一起玩。即使我们长大了，米兰达也总是确保会试着把奥古斯特拉进我们的谈话，问他近况如何，和他谈论《阿凡达》、《星球大战》、《骨头》或者一些她知道他喜欢的东西。是米兰达送给了奥吉那个宇航员头盔，他在五六岁时几乎一年到头都戴着。她会叫他汤姆少校，他们会一起唱大卫·鲍伊的《太空怪谈》。那是他们之间的小默契。他们知道所有的歌词，会把iPod音量开到最大，大声地唱出来。

vocab.word: out of the three of us
vocab.ex: Out of the three of us, she is the best singer.

vocab.mean: 转移到（新的活动或话题）
vocab.ex: After discussing the first topic, let's move on to the next item on the agenda.
Please make sure to include everyone in the decision-making process.
I've been working on this all day; I'm practically finished.

vocab.mean: 汤姆少校（大卫·鲍伊歌曲中的角色）
vocab.ex: The song tells the story of an astronaut named Major Tom.
He loves to blast rock music in his car with the windows down.

gram.name: 强调句型 (It was... who...)
gram.pattern: It was + [emphasized part] + who + [rest of sentence]
gram.function: 用于强调句子中的某个特定部分，通常是动作的执行者。'It was Miranda who had given Auggie the astronaut helmet...' 强调了送头盔的人正是“米兰达”，突显了她在奥吉生活中的特殊角色。

example.en: It was my sister who baked this delicious cake, not me.
example.cn: 是我的姐姐烤了这个美味的蛋糕，不是我。

gram.constraints: 被强调的部分是人时，通常用 'who'。

paras.en: Since Miranda's always been really good about calling us as soon as she got home from summer camp, I was a little surprised when I didn't hear from her. I even texted her and she didn't reply. I figured maybe she had ended up staying in the camp longer, now that she was a counselor. Maybe she met a cute guy. Then I realized from her Facebook wall that she'd actually been back home for a full two weeks, so I sent her an IM and we chatted online a bit, but she didn't give me a reason for not calling, which I thought was bizarre. Miranda had always been a little flaky, so I figured that's all it was. We made plans to meet downtown, but then I had to cancel because we were driving out to visit Tata and Poppa for the weekend.
paras.cn: 由于米兰达从夏令营一回家就给我们打电话这一点上一直都做得很好，所以当我没接到她电话时，我有点惊讶。我甚至给她发了短信，她也没回。我琢磨着也许她最终在营地待得更久了，既然她现在是辅导员。也许她遇到了一个帅哥。然后我从她的脸书主页上意识到，她其实已经回家整整两个星期了，所以我给她发了即时消息，我们在网上聊了一会儿，但她没给我不打电话的理由，我觉得这很奇怪。米兰达一直都有点不靠谱，所以我琢磨着也就是那么回事。我们约好在市中心见面，但后来我不得不取消，因为我们周末要开车去看望塔塔和波帕。

vocab.ex: He's very good about remembering his friends' birthdays.
She worked as a camp counselor during the summer.
If you need a quick answer, just send me an IM.
He told a bizarre story about a talking cat.
He's a bit flaky, so don't be surprised if he cancels at the last minute.
They had to cancel the flight due to bad weather.

gram.name: now that 引导的原因状语从句
gram.pattern: ..., now that + clause
gram.function: 用于引出一个新的、作为当前情况原因的事实，意为“既然；由于现在”。'...she had ended up staying... longer, now that she was a counselor' 解释了“待得更久”这个推测的理由是“她现在是辅导员了”。

example.en: Now that you've finished your homework, you can watch TV.
example.cn: 既然你已经完成了作业，你可以看电视了。

gram.constraints: 强调的是一个新出现的原因。

paras.en: So I ended up not seeing either Miranda or Ella until the first day of school. And, I have to admit, I was shocked. Miranda looked so different: her hair was cut in this super-cute bob that she'd dyed bright pink, of all things, and she was wearing a striped tube top that (a) seemed way inappropriate for school, and (b) was totally not her usual style. Miranda had always been such a prude about clothes, and here she was all pink-haired and tube-topped. But it wasn't just the way she looked that was different: she was acting differently, too. I can't say she wasn't nice, because she was, but she seemed kind of distant, like I was a casual friend. It was the weirdest thing in the world.
paras.cn: 所以我最终直到开学第一天才见到米兰达或埃拉。而且，我得承认，我惊呆了。米兰达看起来太不一样了：她的头发剪成了这种超可爱的波波头，还染成了亮粉色，真是没想到，而且她穿着一件条纹抹胸上衣，这件上衣（a）似乎非常不适合在学校穿，以及（b）完全不是她平时的风格。米兰达在穿着上一直都那么保守，而现在她却是一头粉发，穿着抹胸上衣。但不同的不仅仅是她的外表：她的行为举止也不同了。我不能说她不友善，因为她确实是，但她似乎有点疏远，好像我只是一个普通朋友。这是世界上最奇怪的事情了。

vocab.ex: We wanted to go to the beach, but we ended up at the mall because of the rain.
She decided to cut her long hair into a stylish bob.
He wanted a change, so he decided to dye his hair blue.
He ordered a pineapple pizza, of all things!
Tube tops were very popular in the early 2000s.
Wearing shorts to a formal wedding would be inappropriate.

vocab.mean: （在言行、衣着上）过分拘谨守礼的人
vocab.ex: She's such a prude that she gets embarrassed by the mildest jokes.
After the argument, he became distant and cold.
I know him from work, but we're just casual friends.

gram.name: not just... but... also... 结构
gram.pattern: It wasn't just X that was different: Y was different, too.
gram.function: 用于连接两个并列的成分，强调两者兼备，并且后者是更进一步的补充。'But it wasn't just the way she looked...: she was acting differently, too' 强调了米兰达的变化是全方位的，不仅限于外表。

example.en: It's not just his talent that makes him successful; his hard work is a major factor, too.
example.cn: 让他成功的不仅仅是他的天赋；他的努力也是一个主要因素。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的递进关系表达方式。

paras.en: At lunch the three of us sat together like we always used to, but the dynamics had shifted. It was obvious to me that Ella and Miranda had gotten together a few times during the summer without me, though they never actually said that. I pretended not to be at all upset while we talked, though I could feel my face getting hot, my smile being fake. Although Ella wasn't as over-the-top as Miranda, I noticed a change in her usual style, too. It's like they had talked to each other beforehand about redoing their image at the new school, but hadn't bothered to clue me in. I admit: I had always thought I was above this kind of typical teenage pettiness, but I felt a lump in my throat throughout lunch.
paras.cn: 午餐时我们三个人像往常一样坐在一起，但氛围已经变了。我很明显地感觉到，埃拉和米兰达夏天时在没我的情况下聚过几次，尽管她们从未真正这么说。我们聊天时，我假装一点也不难过，尽管我能感觉到我的脸在发烫，我的笑容是假的。虽然埃拉不像米兰达那么夸张，我也注意到她平时的风格也变了。就好像她们事先商量过要在新学校重塑形象，却懒得通知我一声。我承认：我一直以为我能超脱于这种典型的青少年小心眼，但整个午餐期间我都感到喉头哽咽。

vocab.ex: The team dynamics changed when the new manager arrived.
Public opinion on the issue has started to shift.
It was obvious that he was not happy with the decision.
Let's get together for coffee next week.
Her reaction seemed a little over-the-top for such a small mistake.

vocab.mean: 给某人提供线索；让某人知情
vocab.ex: Can someone clue me in on what's been happening?
She considered herself above such childish arguments.
I'm tired of all the office politics and pettiness.

vocab.mean: 喉头哽咽（因悲伤或激动）
vocab.ex: He felt a lump in his throat as he said goodbye to his family.

gram.name: It's like (用于推测)
gram.pattern: It's like + clause
gram.function: 在非正式语境中，用于引出一个基于观察的推测或解释，意为“就好像…”。'It's like they had talked to each other beforehand...' 是叙述者对自己被排除在外的感觉所做出的一个推论。

example.en: He hasn't spoken all morning. It's like he's angry about something.
example.cn: 他一早上都没说话。就好像他为什么事生气了似的。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的口语化推测方式。

paras.en: My voice quivered as I said "See you later" when the bell rang.
paras.cn: 铃响时，我说“待会儿见”时声音都在发颤。

vocab.ex: Her lip began to quiver as she tried not to cry.

gram.name: 结论性的感官细节
gram.pattern: A final sentence focusing on a single, powerful sensory detail.
gram.function: 通过在章节结尾处聚焦于一个具体的、生理上的反应（'My voice quivered'），作者将叙述者内心的痛苦和被排斥感具象化。这个单一的感官细节比长篇的情感描述更具冲击力，为整个章节的压抑氛围画上了一个有力的句号。

example.en: He walked out into the rain, and a single tear traced a path down his cheek.
example.cn: 他走进雨中，一滴眼泪顺着他的脸颊滑落。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过具体细节来传达强烈情感的文学技巧。

paras.en: "I hear we're driving you home today." It was Miranda in eighth period. She had just sat down at the desk right behind me. I had forgotten that Mom had called Miranda's mother the night before to ask if she could drive me home from school. "You don't have to," I answered instinctively, casually. "My mom can pick me up." "I thought she had to pick Auggie up or something." "It turns out she can pick me up afterward. She just texted me. Not a problem." "Oh. Okay." "Thanks."
paras.cn: “我听说我们今天开车送你回家。” 是米兰达，在第八节课上。她刚在我正后方的课桌坐下。我忘了妈妈前一天晚上给米兰达的妈妈打过电话，问她是否能开车送我放学回家。“你不必的，” 我本能地、随口回答。“我妈妈可以来接我。” “我以为她得去接奥吉什么的。” “结果是她之后可以来接我。她刚给我发了短信。没问题。” “哦。好的。” “谢谢。”

vocab.ex: We have math class in the third period.
The cat reacted instinctively when it saw the mouse.
He casually mentioned that he was moving to another country.
Can you pick me up from the airport tomorrow?
The weather forecast said it would rain, but it turned out to be a sunny day.

gram.name: 回避性对话
gram.pattern: A series of short, polite but distant exchanges.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列简短、礼貌但疏远的对话（'You don't have to', 'Oh. Okay.', 'Thanks.'），作者有效地传达了两个角色之间日益增长的隔阂。对话表面上很正常，但缺乏了以往的亲密感，反映了叙述者想要回避与“新”米兰达互动的意图。

example.en: A: Are you coming? B: I can't. A: Why? B: I'm busy. A: Okay.
example.cn: A：你来吗？B：我不能。A：为什么？B：我忙。A：好吧。

gram.constraints: 对话的简洁性本身就传达了情感信息。

paras.en: It was all a lie on my part, but I couldn't see sitting in a car with the new Miranda. After school I ducked into a restroom to avoid bumping into Miranda's mother outside. Half an hour later I walked out of the school, ran the three blocks to the bus stop, hopped on the M86 to Central Park West, and took the subway home.
paras.cn: 我这边说的全是谎话，但我无法想象和新的米兰达坐在一辆车里。放学后，我躲进一间洗手间，以避免在外面碰到米兰达的妈妈。半小时后，我走出学校，跑了三个街区到公交车站，跳上M86路公交车到中央公园西路，然后坐地铁回家。

vocab.ex: There was no hesitation on my part to accept the offer.
He ducked into a bookstore to escape the sudden rainstorm.
I was surprised to bump into an old friend at the supermarket.
We need to hop on the next bus if we don't want to be late.
Taking the subway is the fastest way to get across the city.

gram.name: 并列动词短语（过去时）
gram.pattern: SUBJ + Verb1, Verb2, and Verb3
gram.function: 用于描述一个主语连续进行的多个动作，使叙事简洁、节奏明快。'...I walked out..., ran..., hopped on..., and took...' 这一系列动词清晰地描绘了叙述者独自回家的过程。

example.en: He came home, dropped his keys on the table, and turned on the TV.
example.cn: 他回到家，把钥匙扔在桌上，然后打开了电视。

gram.constraints: 所有并列的动词时态应保持一致。

paras.en: "Hey there, sweetie!" Mom said the moment I stepped through the front door. "How was your first day? I was starting to wonder where you guys were." "We stopped for pizza." Incredible how easily a lie can slip through your lips. "Is Miranda not with you?" She seemed surprised that Miranda wasn't right behind me. "She went straight home. We have a lot of homework." "On your first day?" "Yes, on our first day!" I yelled, which completely surprised Mom.
paras.cn: “嘿，宝贝！” 我一踏进前门妈妈就说。“第一天怎么样？我正开始纳闷你们去哪儿了。” “我们停下来吃了披萨。” 不可思议，谎言竟能如此轻易地从你嘴里溜出来。“米兰达没和你在一起吗？” 她似乎对米兰达没跟在我身后感到惊讶。“她直接回家了。我们有很多作业。” “第一天就有了？” “是的，第一天就有了！” 我喊道，这完全吓到了妈妈。

vocab.ex: Come here, sweetie, and give me a hug.
As he stepped through the doorway, everyone shouted 'Surprise!'
I wonder what time the movie starts tonight.
He tried to keep the secret, but her name slipped through his lips.

gram.name: 旁白式自我反思
gram.pattern: An independent sentence offering commentary on the action.
gram.function: 在叙述一个动作（撒谎）之后，插入一个独立的、感叹式的句子（'Incredible how easily a lie can slip through your lips.'），作为叙述者对自身行为的即时评论和反思。这种“跳出”叙事的旁白，增强了故事的亲密感，让读者直接进入角色的内心世界。

example.en: He walked past without saying hello. Amazing how quickly people can change.
example.cn: 他走过时没打招呼。真惊人，人可以变得这么快。

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的叙事技巧，用于表达角色的内心感悟。

paras.en: But before she could say anything, I said: "School was fine. It's really big, though. The kids seem nice." I wanted to give her enough information so she wouldn't feel the need to ask me more. "How was Auggie's first day of school?" Mom hesitated, her eyebrows still high up on her forehead from when I'd snapped at her a second earlier. "Okay," she said slowly, like she was letting out a breath.
paras.cn: 但在她能说任何话之前，我说：“学校还行。不过真的很大。孩子们看起来人不错。” 我想给她足够的信息，这样她就不会觉得有必要再问我更多了。“奥吉上学第一天怎么样？” 妈妈犹豫了一下，她的眉毛还高高地扬在额头上，因为我刚才对她发了脾气。“还行，” 她慢慢地说，像是在松一口气。

vocab.ex: He's very independent and doesn't feel the need to ask for help.
She didn't hesitate to help the person in need.

vocab.mean: 对…厉声说；不耐烦地回答
vocab.ex: I'm sorry I snapped at you; I've had a very stressful day.
She let out a breath of relief when she heard the good news.

gram.name: 先发制人的信息给予
gram.pattern: Answering unasked questions to control a conversation.
gram.function: 角色主动提供一系列简短、笼统的信息（'School was fine. It's really big...'），其目的（'so she wouldn't feel the need to ask me more'）是为了控制对话的走向，避免深入讨论自己不想谈论的话题。这是一种回避策略。

example.en: Before she could ask, he said, "Work was fine, traffic was bad, and yes, I remembered to buy milk."
example.cn: 在她能问之前，他就说：“工作还行，交通很糟，是的，我记得买牛奶了。”

gram.constraints: 是一种复杂的社交互动技巧。

paras.en: "What do you mean 'okay'?" I said. "Was it good or bad?" "He said it was good." "So why do you think it wasn't good?" "I didn't say it wasn't good! Geez, Via, what's up with you?" "Just forget I asked anything at all," I answered, and stormed dramatically into Auggie's room and slammed the door. He was on his PlayStation and didn't even look up. I hated how zombified his video games made him.
paras.cn: “你说的‘还行’是什么意思？” 我说。“是好还是坏？” “他说挺好的。” “那你为什么觉得不好？” “我没说不好！天哪，维娅，你怎么了？” “就当我什么都没问过，” 我回答，然后戏剧性地冲进奥吉的房间，并砰地一声关上了门。他正在玩他的PlayStation，甚至都没抬头看一眼。我讨厌电子游戏把他变得像僵尸一样。

vocab.ex: What do you mean you're not coming? You promised!
You seem really quiet today. What's up with you?
After the argument, he stormed out of the house.
She dramatically threw her hands up in the air in frustration.
He was so angry that he slammed the door behind him.
After staring at the screen for hours, he looked completely zombified.

gram.name: 直接对抗性提问
gram.pattern: A series of direct questions demanding specific answers.
gram.function: 通过提出一系列不给对方留有余地的直接问题（'What do you mean...?', 'Was it good or bad?', 'why do you think...'），叙述者将自己的挫败感和焦虑情绪转向了母亲，制造了对话的紧张气氛。

example.en: "Where were you? Who were you with? Why didn't you call?" she asked angrily.
example.cn: “你去哪了？你和谁在一起？你为什么不打电话？” 她愤怒地问。

gram.constraints: 是一种在对话中表达强烈情绪的方式。

paras.en: "So how was school?" I said, scooching Daisy over so I could sit on his bed next to him. "Fine," he answered, still not looking up from his game. "Auggie, I'm talking to you!" I pulled the PlayStation out of his hands. "Hey!" he said angrily. "How was school?" "I said fine!" he yelled back, grabbing the PlayStation back from me. "Were people nice to you?" "Yes!" "No one was mean?" He put the PlayStation down and looked up at me as if I had just asked the dumbest question in the world. "Why would people be mean?" he said. It was the first time in his life that I heard him be sarcastic like that. I didn't think he had it in him.
paras.cn: “那么学校怎么样？” 我说，把黛西挪开，好让我能坐在他旁边的床上。“还行，” 他回答，仍然没有从他的游戏中抬起头。“奥吉，我在跟你说话！” 我从他手里把PlayStation抽了出来。“嘿！” 他生气地说。“学校怎么样？” “我说了还行！” 他吼了回来，从我手里抢回了PlayStation。“大家对你友善吗？” “是的！” “没人刻薄吗？” 他放下PlayStation，抬头看着我，好像我刚问了世界上最蠢的问题似的。“人们为什么要刻薄？” 他说。这是他有生以来我第一次听到他那样讽刺。我从没想过他会那样。

vocab.ex: Could you scooch over a bit so I can sit down?
She pulled a book out of her bag.
The toddler grabbed his toy back from his playmate.
That was the dumbest mistake I have ever made.
His sarcastic comment was not appreciated.

vocab.mean: （某人）没有那样的能力/胆量/性格
vocab.ex: I never thought she had it in her to stand up to the boss, but she did.

gram.name: 反问句（用于讽刺）
gram.pattern: A question with an obvious or implied answer, used to make a point.
gram.function: 奥吉的反问句 'Why would people be mean?' 并不是在寻求答案，而是一种讽刺的回应。这个问题的答案对他来说是如此显而易见（因为他的脸），以至于他用这个问题来反讽姐姐提问的天真，同时也揭示了他对自身处境的深刻（且痛苦的）认知。

example.en: You forgot your keys again? Are you ever going to remember?
example.cn: 你又忘了钥匙？你到底什么时候才能记住？

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的、带有强烈情感色彩的交流方式。

paras.en: I'm not sure at what point that night Auggie had cut off his Padawan braid, or why that made me really mad. I had always found his obsession with everything Star Wars kind of geeky, and that braid in the back of his hair, with its little beads, was just awful. But he had always been so proud of it, of how long it took him to grow it, of how he had chosen the beads himself in a crafts store in Soho. He and Christopher, his best friend, used to play with lightsabers and Star Wars stuff whenever they got together, and they had both started growing their braids at the same time. When August cut his braid off that night, without an explanation, without telling me beforehand (which was surprising)—or even calling Christopher—I was just so upset I can't even explain why.
paras.cn: 我不确定奥吉是那晚什么时候剪掉了他的帕达瓦辫子，也不确定为什么那让我非常生气。我一直觉得他对所有星球大战的东西的痴迷有点书呆子气，而且他后脑勺那根带着小珠子的辫子简直糟透了。但他一直都为它感到非常骄傲，为他花了多长时间才长出来，为他亲自在苏荷区的一家手工店挑选了珠子。他和他的好朋友克里斯托弗，每次聚在一起时都常常玩光剑和星球大战的东西，他们俩是同时开始留辫子的。当奥古斯特那天晚上剪掉他的辫子，没有任何解释，没有事先告诉我（这很令人惊讶）——甚至没有打电话给克里斯托弗——我就是那么难过，甚至无法解释为什么。

vocab.ex: I'm not sure at what point in the movie I fell asleep.
He decided to cut off his long hair for the summer.
She has an obsession with collecting vintage stamps.
He loves talking about computer programming and other geeky topics.
If you had told me beforehand, I could have helped.
She was upset to hear that her friend was moving away.

gram.name: so... (that)... 结构 (用于表达强烈情感)
gram.pattern: so + adjective + (that) + clause
gram.function: 用于强调情感的程度之深，以至于产生了某种结果（例如无法解释）。在此处，'I was just so upset I can't even explain why' 中的连词 'that' 被省略，使语气更口语化、更具情感冲击力。

example.en: The movie was so sad I couldn't stop crying.
example.cn: 那部电影太悲伤了，我哭得停不下来。

gram.constraints: 省略 'that' 在非正式语境中很常见。

paras.en: I've seen Auggie brushing his hair in the bathroom mirror. He meticulously tries to get every hair in place. He tilts his head to look at himself from different angles, like there's some magic perspective inside the mirror that could change the dimensions of his face.
paras.cn: 我见过奥吉在浴室镜子前梳头。他一丝不苟地试图把每根头发都弄到位。他会倾斜着头，从不同的角度看自己，好像镜子里有什么神奇的视角可以改变他脸的尺寸似的。

vocab.ex: She meticulously organized all the books on the shelf.
After cleaning the room, she put everything back in place.
He tilted his head to one side, listening carefully.
Try looking at the problem from a different angle.
From this perspective, the building looks much smaller.
We need to measure the dimensions of the room before buying furniture.

gram.name: 明喻（用于描述充满希望的动作）
gram.pattern: Action + like + hypothetical clause
gram.function: 通过一个比喻来揭示动作背后的希望或意图。'...tilts his head... like there's some magic perspective...' 不仅仅描述了他“如何”看自己，更揭示了他“为何”这样做——仿佛在寻找一个能改变现实的奇迹视角，这深刻地展现了他内心的渴望。

example.en: She checked her phone every five minutes, like she was expecting a call that would change her life.
example.cn: 她每五分钟就查看一次手机，好像在等一个能改变她人生的电话。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过比喻来揭示人物内心状态的文学手法。

paras.en: Mom knocked on my door after dinner. She looked drained, and I realized that between me and Auggie, today had been a tough day for her, too. "So you want to tell me what's up?" she asked nicely, softly. "Not now, okay?" I answered. I was reading. I was tired. Maybe later I'd be up to telling her about Miranda, but not now. "I'll check in before you go to bed," she said, and then she came over and kissed me on the top of my head. "Can Daisy sleep with me tonight?" "Sure, I'll bring her in later." "Don't forget to come back," I said as she left. "I promise."
paras.cn: 晚饭后妈妈敲了我的门。她看起来筋疲力尽，我意识到在我和奥吉之间，今天对她来说也是艰难的一天。“那么你想告诉我出什么事了吗？” 她和善地、轻柔地问。“现在不行，好吗？” 我回答。我正在看书。我累了。也许晚点我会有心情告诉她关于米兰达的事，但不是现在。“你睡觉前我再来看看你，” 她说，然后她走过来亲吻我的头顶。“今晚黛西能和我一起睡吗？” “当然，我晚点把它带进来。” “别忘了回来，” 她离开时我说。“我保证。”

vocab.ex: After running the marathon, he felt completely drained of energy.
It was a tough decision to move to a new city.
You seem really quiet today. What's up?
I'm too tired tonight; I'm not up to going out.
Please check in with me when you get home so I know you're safe.

gram.name: be up to + V-ing 结构 (表示有能力/心情做某事)
gram.pattern: be + (not) + up to + gerund
gram.function: 用于谈论某人是否有情感或身体上的能力去做某件事。'Maybe later I'd be up to telling her...' 表明叙述者当前没有心情或精力去进行一次困难的谈话。

example.en: After a long day at work, I wasn't up to cooking a big meal.
example.cn: 在工作了一整天后，我没心情做一顿大餐。

gram.constraints: 此处的 'to' 是介词，后面必须跟名词或动名词。

paras.en: But she didn't come back that night. Dad did. He told me Auggie had had a bad first day and Mom was helping him through it. He asked me how my day had gone and I told him fine. He said he didn't believe me for a second, and I told him Miranda and Ella were acting like jerks. (I didn't mention how I took the subway home by myself, though.) He said nothing tests friendships like high school, and then proceeded to poke fun at the fact that I was reading War and Peace. Not real fun, of course, since I'd heard him brag to people that he had a "fifteen-year-old who is reading Tolstoy." But he liked to rib me about where I was in the book, in a war part or in a peace part, and if there was anything in there about Napoleon's days as a hip-hop dancer. It was silly stuff, but Dad always managed to make everyone laugh. And sometimes that's all you need to feel better.
paras.cn: 但那天晚上她没有回来。爸爸来了。他告诉我奥吉的第一天过得很糟糕，妈妈正在帮他度过难关。他问我一天过得怎么样，我告诉他很好。他说他一秒钟都不相信，我就告诉他米兰达和埃拉表现得像个混蛋。（不过我没提我是怎么自己坐地铁回家的。）他说没有什么比高中更能考验友谊了，然后接着拿我正在读《战争与和平》这件事开玩笑。当然，不是真的取笑，因为我听过他向别人吹嘘他有一个“正在读托尔斯泰的十五岁女儿”。但他喜欢逗我，问我书读到哪里了，是战争部分还是和平部分，以及书里有没有关于拿破仑当嘻哈舞者的日子。都是些傻话，但爸爸总能让每个人都笑。而有时候，那就是让你感觉好起来所需要的全部。

vocab.ex: Her friends helped her through the difficult time after she lost her job.
I didn't believe his story for a second.
Don't be such a jerk to your little sister.
After finishing his appetizer, he proceeded to eat the main course.
They love to poke fun at their teacher's strange ties.
He's always bragging about how much money he makes.
His older brothers always rib him about his fear of spiders.

gram.name: That's all you need
gram.pattern: That's all + subject + need.
gram.function: 用于强调某件事物是满足某个需求的唯一或最重要的东西。'And sometimes that's all you need to feel better' 表达了一个简单而深刻的感悟：有时候，简单的笑声就足以治愈不快。

example.en: After a long day, a warm cup of tea is all you need to relax.
example.cn: 劳累一天后，一杯暖茶就是你放松所需要的全部。

gram.constraints: 是一种简洁而有力的总结性陈述。

paras.en: "Don't be mad at Mom," he said as he bent down to give me a good-night kiss. "You know how much she worries about Auggie." "I know," I acknowledged. "Want the light on or off? It's getting kind of late," he said, pausing by the light switch at the door. "Can you bring Daisy in first?" Two seconds later he came back with Daisy dangling in his arms, and he laid her down next to me on the bed. "Good night, sweetheart," he said, kissing my forehead. He kissed Daisy on her forehead, too. "Good night, girlie. Sweet dreams."
paras.cn: “别生妈妈的气，” 他弯下腰给我一个晚安吻时说。“你知道她有多担心奥吉。” “我知道，” 我承认道。“灯开着还是关着？天有点晚了，” 他说，在门口的电灯开关旁停顿了一下。“你能先带黛西进来吗？” 两秒钟后，他抱着摇摇晃晃的黛西回来了，把她放在我旁边的床上。“晚安，甜心，” 他说，亲吻我的额头。他也亲了黛西的额头。“晚安，小姑娘。做个好梦。”

vocab.ex: Please don't be mad at me for being late.
He had to bend down to pick up the coin from the floor.
She was forced to acknowledge her mistake.
Can you find the light switch in the dark?
A single charm was dangling from her bracelet.
She kissed her son on the forehead and wished him sweet dreams.

gram.name: 省略问句
gram.pattern: Verb + Object + Choice?
gram.function: 一种非常口语化的提问方式，通过省略主语和助动词（'Do you'）来使句子更简洁、更直接。'Want the light on or off?' 是 'Do you want the light on or off?' 的非正式形式。

example.en: Need any help with those bags?
example.cn: 那些包需要帮忙吗？

gram.constraints: 常见于非正式对话中。

paras.en: Once, I got up in the middle of the night because I was thirsty, and I saw Mom standing outside Auggie's room. Her hand was on the doorknob, her forehead leaning on the door, which was ajar. She wasn't going in his room or stepping out: just standing right outside the door, as if she was listening to the sound of his breathing as he slept. The hallway lights were out. The only thing illuminating her was the blue nightlight in August's bedroom. She looked ghostlike standing there. Or maybe I should say angelic. I tried to walk back into my room without disturbing her, but she heard me and walked over to me.
paras.cn: 有一次，我半夜起来，因为口渴，我看到妈妈站在奥吉的房门外。她的手放在门把手上，额头靠在半开的门上。她不是要进他的房间，也不是要出来：只是站在门外，好像在听他睡着时的呼吸声。走廊的灯都关了。唯一照亮她的是奥古斯特卧室里的蓝色夜灯。她站在那里像个鬼魂。或者也许我该说像天使。我试图不打扰她走回我的房间，但她听到了我，并向我走来。

vocab.word: in the middle of the night
vocab.ex: He woke up in the middle of the night with a brilliant idea.
She turned the doorknob quietly so as not to wake the baby.
He left the door ajar so the cat could get in and out.
The moonlight was enough to illuminate the path.
The child was afraid of the dark, so they left a nightlight on in his room.
In the fog, the old tree had a strange, ghostlike appearance.
The sleeping baby had an angelic expression on her face.
Please do not disturb the artist while she is working.

gram.name: 独立主格结构（用于描述）
gram.pattern: Noun + participle/prepositional phrase
gram.function: 在句子中作状语，提供附加的细节或背景描述，其逻辑主语与主句主语不同。'Her hand was on the doorknob, her forehead leaning on the door...' 这一系列独立主格结构描绘了一幅静态而充满情感的画面，生动地展示了母亲担忧的姿态。

example.en: He sat in the chair, his eyes closed and his hands folded in his lap.
example.cn: 他坐在椅子上，闭着眼睛，双手交叠放在腿上。

gram.constraints: 是一种高级的文学描述手法，用于创造生动的意象。

paras.en: "Is Auggie okay?" I asked. I knew that sometimes he would wake up choking on his own saliva if he accidentally turned over on his back. "Oh, he's fine," she said, wrapping her arms around me. She walked me back into my room, pulled the covers over me, and kissed me good night. She never explained what she was doing outside his door, and I never asked.
paras.cn: “奥吉还好吗？” 我问。我知道有时如果他不小心翻身仰卧，他会因为自己的唾液而呛醒。“哦，他很好，” 她说，用双臂环绕着我。她送我回我的房间，给我盖上被子，并给了我一个晚安吻。她从未解释过她在他门外做什么，我也从未问过。

vocab.ex: Be careful not to choke on that large piece of meat.
The smell of delicious food makes your mouth produce saliva.
I accidentally broke my mother's favorite vase.
He couldn't sleep and kept turning over in bed.
She wrapped her arms around her friend in a warm hug.
She gently pulled the covers over her sleeping child.

gram.name: 并列否定陈述（用于表达默契）
gram.pattern: Subject 1 + never + Verb 1, and Subject 2 + never + Verb 2.
gram.function: 通过两个并列的、结构相似的否定句 'She never explained... and I never asked'，作者深刻地揭示了家庭成员之间一种心照不宣的默契和界限。这种“不说”和“不问”的平行结构，比直接描述更能体现他们之间复杂的情感动态。

example.en: He never mentioned the money, and I never brought it up.
example.cn: 他从未提及那笔钱，我也从未提起。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行为（或不行为）来展示人物关系的文学技巧。

paras.en: I wonder how many nights she's stood outside his door. And I wonder if she's ever stood outside my door like that.
paras.cn: 我想知道有多少个夜晚她曾站在他的门外。我也想知道她是否曾那样站在我的门外。

vocab.ex: I wonder what time the movie starts tonight.
Don't speak to your mother like that; it's disrespectful.

gram.name: 首语重复法（用于表达渴望）
gram.pattern: Repetition of a phrase at the beginning of successive clauses.
gram.function: 通过重复 'I wonder...'，作者将两个问题并列起来，创造了一种强烈的对比。第一个 'wonder' 是对母亲行为的推测，而第二个 'wonder' 则转为对自身被爱的渴望和不确定性。这种重复和对比深刻地揭示了叙述者内心深处的渴望和作为“被忽视”的孩子的孤独感。

example.en: I wonder where he is now. And I wonder if he ever thinks of me.
example.cn: 我想知道他现在在哪里。我也想知道他是否曾想起我。

gram.constraints: 是一种强有力的修辞手法，用于表达深度的思考和情感。

paras.en: "Can you pick me up from school today?" I said the next morning, smearing some cream cheese on my bagel. Mom was making August's lunch (American cheese on whole-wheat bread, soft enough for Auggie to eat) while August sat eating oatmeal at the table. Dad was getting ready to go to work. Now that I was in high school, the new school routine was going to be that Dad and I would take the subway together in the morning, which meant his having to leave fifteen minutes earlier than usual, then I'd get off at my stop and he'd keep going. And Mom was going to pick me up after school in the car.
paras.cn: “你今天能来学校接我吗？” 第二天早上我一边在百吉饼上涂抹奶油奶酪一边说。妈妈正在做奥古斯特的午餐（全麦面包夹美国奶酪，软到奥吉能吃），而奥古斯特正坐在桌边吃燕麦片。爸爸正准备去上班。既然我上了高中，新的上学常规将是爸爸和我在早上一起坐地铁，这意味着他得比平时早十五分钟出门，然后我在我的站下车，他继续前行。而妈妈则会在放学后开车来接我。

vocab.ex: He likes to smear a thick layer of jam on his toast.
A toasted bagel with cream cheese is a classic breakfast.
For breakfast, she had a poppy seed bagel.
A warm bowl of oatmeal is a healthy way to start the day.
My morning routine includes a cup of coffee and reading the news.

gram.name: 所有格 + 动名词
gram.pattern: Possessive (his) + GERUND-ing
gram.function: 在动名词前使用所有格（如 my, your, his, John's），可以明确指出该动作的执行者。这是一种较为正式的书面语用法。'...which meant his having to leave...' 中，'his having to leave' 指的是“他不得不离开”这件事。

example.en: I was surprised by his suddenly quitting the job.
example.cn: 我对他突然辞职感到惊讶。

variants: Object Pronoun + GERUND-ing (less formal, e.g., 'him having to leave')
gram.constraints: 在正式语境中，使用所有格更受青睐。

paras.en: "I was going to call Miranda's mother to see if she could drive you home again," Mom answered. "No, Mom!" I said quickly. "You pick me up. Or I'll just take the subway." "You know I don't want you to take the subway by yourself yet," she answered. "Mom, I'm fifteen! Everybody my age takes the subway by themselves!"
paras.cn: “我正打算给米兰达的妈妈打电话，看她是否能再开车送你回家，” 妈妈回答。“不，妈妈！” 我迅速说。“你来接我。或者我就自己坐地铁。” “你知道我还不希望你一个人坐地铁，” 她回答。“妈，我十五岁了！我这个年纪的每个人都自己坐地铁！”

vocab.ex: I was going to clean my room, but I ran out of time.
Can you pick me up from the airport tomorrow?
He learned how to cook all by himself.

gram.name: 一般现在时祈使语气（用于要求）
gram.pattern: Subject + Verb (simple present)
gram.function: 虽然 'You pick me up' 在语法上是一般现在时陈述句，但在对话的上下文中，它带有强烈的指令或要求意味，比标准的祈使句 'Pick me up' 语气更强硬、更具个人化。

example.en: You will do your homework now, and you will not complain.
example.cn: 你现在就去做作业，不许抱怨。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过句法选择来传达语气的常见方式。

paras.en: "She can take the subway by herself," Dad insisted. Mom looked at both of us. "Is something going on?" She didn't address her question to either one of us in particular. "You would know if you had come back to check on me," I said spitefully, "like you said you would." "Oh God, Via," said Mom, remembering now how she had completely ditched me last night. She put down the knife she was using to cut Auggie's grapes in half (still a choking hazard for him because of the size of his palate). "I am so sorry. I fell asleep in Auggie's room. By the time I woke up . . ."
paras.cn: “她可以自己坐地铁，” 爸爸坚持说。妈妈看着我们俩。“是出什么事了吗？” 她的问题没有特别针对我们中的任何一个。“如果你昨晚回来看看我，你就会知道了，” 我恶狠狠地说，“就像你说你会的那样。” “哦天哪，维娅，” 妈妈说，现在想起了她昨晚是如何完全把我给忘了。她放下她正在用来把奥吉的葡萄切成两半的刀（由于他上颚的大小，这对他来说仍然有窒息的危险）。“我非常非常抱歉。我在奥吉的房间里睡着了。等我醒来的时候……”

vocab.ex: He kept insisting he was right, even when we showed him the evidence.
Please address your questions to the speaker after the presentation.
She spitefully told his secret to everyone.
He decided to ditch his old friends when he became famous.
Small toys can be a choking hazard for young children.

gram.name: 混合条件句（过去对现在的影响）
gram.pattern: If + past perfect, ... would + infinitive
gram.function: 用于描述一个与过去事实相反的假设（'if you had come back' - 实际上没回来），以及这个假设对现在可能产生的结果（'You would know' - 实际上现在不知道）。

example.en: If I had taken your advice, I wouldn't be in this mess now.
example.cn: 如果我当初听了你的建议，我现在就不会陷入这个烂摊子了。

gram.constraints: 连接了对过去的假设和对现在的影响。

paras.en: "I know, I know." I nodded indifferently. Mom came over, put her hands on my cheeks, and lifted my face to look at her. "I'm really, really sorry," she whispered. I could tell she was. "It's okay!" I said. "Via . . ." "Mom, it's fine." This time I meant it. She looked so genuinely sorry I just wanted to let her off the hook.
paras.cn: “我知道，我知道。” 我冷漠地点了点头。妈妈走过来，把手放在我的脸颊上，抬起我的脸看着她。“我真的、真的非常抱歉，” 她低声说。我看得出她是真心的。“没关系！” 我说。“维娅……” “妈，没事。” 这次我是真心的。她看起来是那么真诚地感到抱歉，我只是想放她一马。

vocab.ex: He shrugged indifferently, as if he didn't care about the outcome.
She couldn't lift the heavy box by herself.
I am genuinely grateful for all your help.

vocab.mean: 放某人一马；让某人摆脱困境
vocab.ex: The teacher let him off the hook for being late because his bus was delayed.

gram.name: 结果状语从句（省略 that）
gram.pattern: so + adj/adv + clause
gram.function: 用于强调程度之深以至于产生了某种结果。在口语化的叙述中，连词 'that' 常常被省略。'She looked so genuinely sorry I just wanted to...' 强调了妈妈歉意的程度，以及这种程度所导致的后果（女儿想原谅她）。

example.en: He ran so fast he was out of breath.
example.cn: 他跑得太快了，以至于上气不接下气。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的非正式用法。

paras.en: She kissed and hugged me, then returned to the grapes. "So, is something going on with Miranda?" she asked. "Just that she's acting like a complete jerk," I said. "Miranda's not a jerk!" Auggie quickly chimed in. "She can be!" I yelled. "Believe me." "Okay then, I'll pick you up, no problem," Mom said decisively, sweeping the half-grapes into a snack bag with the side of her knife. "That was the plan all along anyway. I'll pick Auggie up from school in the car and then we'll pick you up. We'll probably get there about a quarter to four."
paras.cn: 她亲吻并拥抱了我，然后回去处理葡萄。“那么，是米兰达出了什么事吗？” 她问。“只是她表现得像个十足的混蛋，” 我说。“米兰达不是混蛋！” 奥吉迅速插话。“她可以是的！” 我喊道。“相信我。” “好吧，那么我去接你，没问题，” 妈妈果断地说，用刀边把切半的葡萄扫进一个零食袋里。“反正那本来就是计划。我会开车去学校接奥吉，然后我们再来接你。我们大概会在三点四十五分到那里。”

vocab.ex: Don't be such a jerk to your little sister.
As we were discussing the movie, my little brother chimed in with his opinion.
She acted decisively to solve the problem before it got worse.
He used a brush to sweep the crumbs into the dustpan.
I knew the secret all along, but I didn't say anything.
The meeting is scheduled to start at a quarter to four.

gram.name: 省略回答
gram.pattern: A noun clause as a full answer.
gram.function: 使用一个名词性从句来直接回答问题，省略了主句（如 'The thing is...'）。'Just that she's acting like a complete jerk' 是对 'is something going on with Miranda?' 这个问题的直接、简洁且充满情感的回答。

example.en: A: Why are you so happy? B: Just that I passed my exam!
example.cn: A：你为什么这么开心？B：就因为我通过了考试！

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的口语化回答方式。

paras.en: "No!" I said firmly, before she'd even finished. "Isabel, she can take the subway!" said Dad impatiently. "She's a big girl now. She's reading War and Peace, for crying out loud." "What does War and Peace have to with anything?" answered Mom, clearly annoyed. "It means you don't have to pick her up in the car like she's a little girl," he said sternly. "Via, are you ready? Get your bag and let's go."
paras.cn: “不！” 我在她还没说完时就坚决地说。“伊莎贝尔，她可以坐地铁！” 爸爸不耐烦地说。“她现在是个大女孩了。她正在读《战争与和平》，搞什么名堂啊。” “《战争与和平》和这有什么关系？” 妈妈回答，显然很恼火。“那意味着你不必像她还是个小女孩一样开车去接她，” 他严厉地说。“维娅，你准备好了吗？拿上你的包，我们走。”

vocab.ex: She firmly believed that she was right.
He tapped his foot impatiently while waiting in line.

vocab.mean: （表示不耐烦或惊讶）搞什么名堂啊；天哪
vocab.ex: Oh, for crying out loud, can you please stop making that noise!
What does your personal life have to do with your job performance?
She was annoyed with him for being late.
"Do your homework now," he said sternly.

gram.name: 文学典故作为论据
gram.pattern: Using a reference to a complex work to support a point.
gram.function: 父亲通过提及维娅正在阅读《战争与和平》这本厚重而复杂的文学作品，来作为她已经“长大”、“成熟”的论据，以此来反驳母亲的过度保护。这是一种通过文化符号来增强论证说服力的修辞手法。

example.en: You're acting like Romeo, falling in love so quickly.
example.cn: 你表现得像罗密欧一样，这么快就坠入爱河。

gram.constraints: 其效果依赖于听者对所引用典故的理解。

paras.en: "I'm ready," I said, pulling on my backpack. "Bye, Mom! Bye, Auggie!" I kissed them both quickly and headed toward the door. "Do you even have a MetroCard?" Mom said after me. "Of course she has a MetroCard!" answered Dad, fully exasperated. "Yeesh, Momma! Stop worrying so much! Bye," he said, kissing her on the cheek. "Bye, big boy," he said to August, kissing him on the top of his head. "I'm proud of you. Have a good day." "Bye, Daddy! You too."
paras.cn: “我准备好了，” 我说，背上我的背包。“再见，妈妈！再见，奥吉！” 我飞快地亲了他们俩，然后朝门口走去。“你到底有没有地铁卡？” 妈妈在我身后说。“她当然有地铁卡！” 爸爸回答，完全被激怒了。“哎呀，妈咪！别担心那么多了！再见，” 他说，亲吻她的脸颊。“再见，大男孩，” 他对奥古斯特说，亲吻他的头顶。“我为你骄傲。祝你有美好的一天。” “再见，爸爸！你也是。”

vocab.ex: He quickly pulled on his jacket and ran out the door.
After the movie, we decided to head toward the nearest ice cream shop.
You need to swipe your MetroCard to enter the subway station.
The teacher became exasperated with the students' constant chatter.

vocab.mean: （表示懊恼、嫌恶的感叹词）哎呀
vocab.ex: Yeesh, that smells awful!

gram.name: 对比父母角色
gram.pattern: One parent worrying vs. the other parent reassuring/being exasperated.
gram.function: 通过妈妈不断提出担忧的问题（'Do you even have a MetroCard?'）和爸爸不耐烦地肯定女儿的能力（'Of course she has...'），作者生动地展现了家庭中常见的父母角色分工：一个过度担忧，另一个则鼓励独立。这种对话冲突揭示了他们不同的育儿理念。
